ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned a lot of writing skills and grammar in this class. I actually thoroughly enjoyed all the discussions and the small classroom of students. It made it a lot more intimate and fun getting close to the other students.
I learned how to craft a better, well thought out essay.

I learned very useful writing techniques and this course allowed my writing to improve significantly. We analyzed essays and learned moves from authors. We also gave each other constructive feedback in class which was helpful.
I learned better how to read modern essays for craft and content. I learned also how to write in this style.
The ability to write creative nonfiction, to analyze journalistic writing, and to participate in active discussion about the two.
Nonfiction writing tools
I learned how to structure personal essays, how to write more clearly, and how to generally write a place, profile, and humor essay. I also learned about grammar.

I developed a better understanding of the creative writing process, specifically my own. Also, I think as well as this insight about myself, I have gained knowledge about a variety of writing devices, especially when it comes to my own voice being used in writing.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Its the best taught class Ive taken here at Yale. There are no weaknesses
The syllabus for this course is so well crafted and as a result of this, every essay feels important. The timing between first drafts and final drafts is perfect and I never felt overwhelmed.
The readings are very enjoyable. They are also very helpful for writing the essays. Weaknesses are that the workshops are a little bit less helpful than they could be.

Strengths: feedback and assignments style was great! I loved the little mini assignments we did.

Improvements: I feel like some of the readings could have been updated and improved, sometimes class was a bit unstructured and therefore a bit less engaging.

The strengths would be the collaboration that students have to do in this class. Whether it is a workshop, discussing readings with each other, or first drafts. These all come a long way when writing an essay. For weaknesses, I don't think there is any.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Absolutely, the best way to get a writing credit and actually learn how to write better
Yes, this course is great if you are simply trying to explore/improve your writing. The essay prompts allow you to be creative and reflect on yourself.

I most definitely would! If you have the chance to take it with Pam, please do! Im a STEM major and this was one of my two favorite courses at Yale. I took this class originally just as a writing course but I loved writing the essays for class and came excited to class everyday.
Yes. I think that this course actually helps your writing style.
Yes I really enjoyed being creative in this course.
I think students should definitely take 120 because it helps you become a more well rounded writer.

I would recommend this course to another student. The class is full of short, engaging, and interesting pieces of creative writing. This is not your typical writing class where you need to have an intro, 3 body paragraphs, and a conclusion. You don't have to make a structure and most of the sources you use are from your personal experiences. Along with this, you get to explore yourself as a writer which I personally enjoyed.
